meanings.sent1: She decided to remould the clay into a different shape.
meanings.sent2: The artist used her hands to remould the sculpture until it looked perfect.
meanings.sent3: Trying to remould a broken cookie back into its original form is a futile task.
meanings.sent4: After the storm, nature began to remould the landscape with its powerful winds.
meanings.sent5: The potter's hands skillfully remoulded the lump of clay into a beautiful vase.

meanings.definition: To give a new form or structure to
meanings.sent1: The architect had to remould the building plans to accommodate the new requirements.
meanings.sent2: With determination, she managed to remould her life after facing a difficult situation.
meanings.sent3: The child tried to remould the sandcastle into a fortress, but it kept collapsing.
meanings.sent4: Time has the power to remould memories, sometimes making them seem different than they were.
meanings.sent5: The caterpillar will remould itself into a butterfly through the process of metamorphosis.

meanings.definition: To adapt or modify for a new purpose
meanings.sent1: He had to remould his presentation to suit the interests of the audience.
meanings.sent2: The company decided to remould its marketing strategy to reach a wider demographic.
meanings.sent3: The old furniture was remoulded into a unique piece by a skilled craftsman.
meanings.sent4: She had to remould her study habits to succeed in the new school environment.
meanings.sent5: The chef had to remould the recipe to accommodate the dietary restrictions of the guests.
